title: Exponents and Roots
content:
Exponents and roots are inverse operations—exponents repeatedly multiply, while roots "undo" that multiplication. Master the rules of exponents and you'll breeze through these problems on the ACT!

What are Exponents?

2⁵ = 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 = 32: 2

Base - The number being multiplied

5: Exponent

How many times to multiply

Exponent Rules

Product Rule

xa× xb= xa + b: When multiplying same bases,addexponents

2³ × 2⁴ = 2⁷: xa/ xb= xa−b

Quotient Rule

When dividing same bases,subtractexponents

5⁸ / 5³ = 5⁵: (xa)b= xa × b

Power Rule

When raising a power to a power,multiplyexponents

(3²)⁴ = 3⁸: x⁰ = 1

Zero Exponent

Anything to the zero power equals 1 (except 0⁰): 999⁰ = 1

Negative Exponent

x−a= 1/xa

Negative exponent means "flip it"

2−3= 1/2³ = 1/8: √16 = 4 because 4² = 16

Square Roots and Radicals

The square root "undoes" squaring

Common Square Roots to Memorize:

√1 = 1: √4 = 2

√9 = 3: √16 = 4

√25 = 5: √36 = 6

√49 = 7: √64 = 8

√81 = 9: √100 = 10

√121 = 11: √144 = 12

Radical Rules

Multiplication

√a × √b = √(ab): √2 × √8 = √16 = 4

Division

√a / √b = √(a/b): √50 / √2 = √25 = 5

Example Problem

Example 1

Problem:Simplify: x⁵ × x³: A. x⁸
B. x¹⁵
C. x²
D. 2x⁸

Solution:Use the product rule: when multiplying same bases, add the exponents.

x⁵ × x³ = x

5+3

= x⁸

Answer: A

Key Takeaway

Remember the three main rules: add exponents when multiplying (xa× xb= xa + b), subtract when dividing (xa/ xb= xa−b), and multiply when raising a power to a power ((xa)b= xab)!
